中軍 Central Army.text:
中領軍

領軍將軍

行領軍

Commander of the Central Army

General Commanding the Army

Acting Commander of the Army

中領軍

領軍

前領軍

行領軍

Commander of the Central Army

Commander of the Army

Commander of the Front Army

Acting Commander of the Army

領軍將軍

左領軍

右領軍

General Commanding the Army

General Commanding the Left Army

General Commanding the Right Army
(Wei) In charge of the imperial guards

魏制，中領軍領五校﹑中壘﹑武衞三營；其資重者為領軍將軍，資輕者為中領軍，出征則置行領軍

In Wei, the Commander of the Central Army directed the three camps led by the Five Commandants, General of the Central Garrison and General of the Martial Guard. Those with higher prestige and experience held the title General Commanding the Army, while those of lower prestige and experienced held the title Commander of the Central Army; when on campaign, an Acting Commander of the Army would be appointed

Protector of the Central Army

General Protecting the Army

前、後、左、右護軍護軍

護軍

行護軍

中監軍

中、後典軍

Protector of the Front/Rear/Left/Right Army

Protector of the Army

Acting Protector of the Army

Supervisor of the Central Army

Director of the Central/Rear Army

Protector of the Central/Left/Right Army

Protector of the Army
(魏)掌禁兵，亦總統諸將任，主武官選擧
(Wei) In charge of the imperial guards, also oversee appointments of various generals and manage the selection and promotion of military officials

魏制，護軍儘以文屬領軍，領軍闕則護軍代其職; 資重者為護軍將軍，資輕者為護軍。
In Wei, the Protector of the Army was only a nominal bureaucratic subordinate to the Commander of the Army; when the Commander of the Army was not filled, the Protector of the Army acted in his place. Those with higher prestige and experience held the title General Protecting the Army, while those of lower prestige and experienced held the title Protector of the Central Army

蜀制，典軍次護軍，護軍次監軍
In Shu, the Director rank lower than the Protector, and the Protector rank lower than the Supervisor

General of the Martial Guards

Gentleman-General the Martial Guards
Fourth grade, Equivalent to 2000 dan, 1 person

漢制，諸校尉皆領士七百人，惟長水領烏桓胡騎七百三十六人
During Han, each Colonel led 700 soliders, except for the Changshui Regiment which had 736 Wuhuan Hu Cavalries

又，魏晉沿漢制，但職位漸輕
Also, though these five colonels were inherited in the Wei-Jin period, their importance gradually declined
七品，千石，每校尉各一人
Seventh grade, 1000 dan, 1 person for each Colonel
Ninth grade, 1 person for each Colonel

城門 Capital Gates.text:
洛陽城十二門，東有三門，其北曰建春門，次南曰東陽門，次南曰清明門；南有四門，其東曰開陽門，次西曰平昌門，次西曰宣陽門，次西曰津陽門；西有三門，其南曰廣陽門，次北曰西明門，次北曰閶闔門；北有二門，其東曰廣莫門，其西曰大夏門
Luoyang City had twelve gates. On the east side were three: to the north, Jianchun Gate; then, Dongyang Gate; and then to the south, Qingming Gate. On the south side were four: starting from the east, Kaiyang Gate, followed by Pingchang Gate, then Xuanyang Gate, and furthest west, Jinyang Gate. On the west side were three: to the south, Guangyang Gate; then, Ximing Gate; and furthest north, Changhe Gate. On the north side were two gates: to the east, Guangmo Gate, and to the west, Daxia Gate
In charge of the 12 city gates of Luoyang
Fourth grade, Equivalent to 2000 dan, 1 person

吳仿漢制，掌京師諸門
Wu followed the Han system, therefore established the Colonel for the city gates of its capital
In charge of guarding the city gates
Seventh grade, 1000 dan, 1 person for each gate
七品，六百石，每門各一人
Seventh grade, 600 dan, 1 person for each gate

諸都督軍事 Various Commanders.text:
多為加官
Commonly only as an additional title

魏制，不常置，假黃鉞則專戮節將
In Wei, not regularly appointed; whenever conferred together with the Yue, the holder would be granted the authority to execute even generals boring the Imperial Staff

時不加大都督，但稱督中外軍事，職同
Sometimes not given the additional title Grand Commander, only known as Commander of All Forces; the duties are the same

都督

都督諸州軍事

持節都督

Commander

Commander of Provincial Forces

Commander with Imperial Staff
Fourth grade, no fixed number of posts

黃初三年始置都督諸州軍事領剌史，使持節爲上，持節次之，假節爲下。使持節得殺二千石以下，持節殺無宫位人，若軍事得𫟋使持節同。假節惟軍事得殺犯軍令者
In the 3rd year of Huangchu first established Commander of Provincial Forces concurrently holding the office of Inspector. Those appointed as the Envoy with Imperial Staff ranked highest; those only bearing the Imperial Staff ranked next; those with Provisional Imperial Staff ranked below them. An official who is also Envoy with Imperial Staff can execute officials of 2000 dan and below; an official who only bears the Imperial Staff can execute civilians, though in military situations held the same authority as that of the Envoy with Imperial Staff. An official with only the Provisional Imperial Staff can execute only those who violated military law

蜀吳多於邊郡要塞置都督
Shu and Wu often had Commanders near borders or key strongholds
Fifth grade, no fixed number of posts

皆隨諸州都督置，也稱護軍
Established together with the Commander of various provinces, sometimes just known as Protector of the Army
Fourth grade, no fixed number of posts

諸州時或不置都督，則加官置此官
Sometimes the various provinces did not appoint Commanders, then this position is conferred as an additional title

及將軍領兵出征者皆置監軍
When generals go on expeditions, Army Supervisors will be appointed

Protector of the Army

Director of the Army
Sixth grade, no fixed number of posts

諸要鎭及將軍領兵岀征者皆置此官
Various key towns and whenever generals go on expeditions, officials would be appointed for this position

諸大將軍 Various Grand Generals.text:
General of Agile Cavalry

General of Agile Cavalry on the Right

魚豢曰：魏世驃騎車騎為都督，儀與四征同，若不為都督，雖持節屬四征者，與前後左右雜號將軍同。其或散還從文官之例，則位次三司
Yu Huan states: In Wei, the General of Agile Cavalry and General of Chariots and Cavalry, if served as a Grand Commander, his ceremonial rank and status were equivalent to that of the Four Conquering Generals. If he did not serve as a Grand Commander, then even if he held an Imperial Staff like the Four Conquering Generals, he would only be regarded the same as Four Direction and other Miscellaneous Generals. If he was detached from military duty and returned as a civil official, he would rank just below the Three Excellencies.

蜀景耀初復増置右驃騎將軍，分置左右車騎將軍
At the beginning of Jingyao era, Shu added General of Agile Cavalry on the Right, and also split to establish General of Chariots and Cavalry on the Left/Right

秩比三公
Rank equivalent to that of the Three Excellencies

車騎將軍

左、右車騎將軍

General of Chariots and Cavalry

General of Chariots and Cavalry on the Left/Right
Grand General of the Central Army

黃初三年置，後不常設
Established in the 3rd year of Huangchu, later no longer regularly appointed
Grand General of the Upper Army
Grand General Who Guards the Army
Grand General Who Guards the Army
Grand General Who Guards the Army

魏黃初六年置，後不常設
In Wei, established in the 6th year of Huangchu, later no longer regularly appointed
Grand General Who Conciliates the Army

魏黃初五年置
In Wei, established in the 5th year of Huangchu
Grand General of the Southern Interior

咸熙二年置，以吳將來降拜，不常設
Established in the 2nd year of Xianxi, conferred to Wu generals who surrendered to Wei, not regularly appointed
Grand Bulwark General of the State

咸熙元年置，不常設
Established in the 1st year of Xianxi, not regularly appointed

If the general also held the Imperial Staff and was a Grand Commander, then there would be six people

四征四鎮 Conquering & Garrisoning.text:
General Who Conquers the East

Grand General Who Conquers the East

黃初中位次三公；領兵屯揚州治所，統靑兖徐揚四州剌史
In the Huangchu era ranked second to the Three Excellencies; led troops to station at the administrative seat of Yang province, overseeing the inspectors of Qing, Yan, Xu, and Yang provinces

資深者爲大將軍
Those with seniority were appointed as Grand Conquering Generals

General Who Conquers the South

Grand General Who Conquers the South

魏制同征東，領兵屯新野，統荆豫二州剌史
In Wei similar to General Who Conquers the East; led troops to station at Xinye, overseeing the inspectors Jing and Yu provinces

General Who Conquers the West

Grand General Who Conquers the West

General Who Conquers the West

Grand General Who Conquers the West

魏制同征東，領兵屯薊，統幽冀并三州剌史
In Wei similar to General Who Conquers the East; led troops to station at Ji, overseeing the inspectors of You, Ji and Bing provinces

蜀亦以資深者為大將軍
Shu also had those with seniority appointed as Grand Conquering Generals

魏制同征東，領兵屯長安，統雍涼二州剌史
In Wei similar to General Who Conquers the East; led troops to station at Chang'an, overseeing the inspectors of Yong and Liang provinces

魏時征北不常置，故也云三征
In Wei times, the General Who Conquers the North was not regularly appointed, hence sometimes also collectively referred to as the Three Conquering Generals

General Who Garrisons the East

Grand General Who Garrisons the East

General Who Garrisons the East

Grand General Who Garrisons the East

General Who Garrisons the East

Grand General Who Garrisons the East

位次四征，領兵如四征；惟蜀以四征次四鎮
Rank below the Four Conquering Generals, but command troops in the same fashion. Only Shu had the Four Conqeuring Generals below the Four Garrisoning Generals

魏制居是官者皆以功次轉四征，黄初以後諸路征鎮不並置
In Wei, those who held this post typically advanced to the Four Conquering Generals based on merit. After the Huangchu era, the various Conquering and Suppressing generals for different regions were no longer concurrently appointed

四方及雜號 Four Direction & Misc.text:
魏四方次征鎮安平
In Wei, the Four Direction Generals are ranked below the Conquering, Garrisoning, Pacifying and Subduing Generals

蜀四方位鎮安平征之上
In Shu, the Four Direction Generals are ranked above the Garrisoning, Pacifying, Subduing and Conquering Generals

以上四方將軍，官屬同四平
The above are the Four Direction Generals, subordiniates same as those of the Four Subduing

以下三品雜號將者，在九卿上，官屬亦同四平
Those Miscellaneous Generals of the third grade rank above the Nine Ministers, subordiniates are also the same as those of the Four Subduing

军事，中军将最尊，居中以坚锐自辅，故曰中坚也。
The commander of the central army occupied the heart of the formation and was supported by elite troops; thus, the title ‘Zhongjian’ (Central Vanguard) was used

中郎將 Gentleman-Generals.text: In charge of the palace guards
四品，(魏)比二千石，各一人
Fourth grade, (Wei) Equivalent to 2000 dan, 1 person each
(魏)主冶事 (蜀) 亦典作農戰之器

(Wei) In chrage of metal-processing matters
(Shu) Also direct the production of agricultural and military equipment

郡國鐵官本屬司農，中興皆屬郡縣。曹公始置司金，利權盡歸于上矣
The Metal Offices in the commanderies and states originally were subodinates to the Minister of Agriculture, but after the Zhongxing era they were all placed under the respective commanderies and counties. Excellency Cao established the Gentleman-General of Metal Affairs, and thus all profit and authority were returned to the central government
Responsible for music standards and matters
Responsible for protecting the Southern Chanyu

太和五年始置
First established in the 5th year of Taihe
Given to Yi (Non-Han) people that had submitted to Wei

俱倭國使
All appointees were envoys from the State of Wa
Assist the Gentleman-General of Rectification in the surveillance of officials

校尉都尉 Colonels & Commandants.text: Fourth grade, Equivalent to 2000 dan, 1 person

黃初三年西域內附始置，治高昌
Established in the 3rd year of Huangchu, when the Western Regions submitted to Wei, stationed at Gaochang

治廣寧，田豫屯昌平蓋非常制
Stationed at Guangning; when Tian Yu garrisoned at Changping, it was likely an exception outside the norm

以下為上述四品校尉屬官
Below are the subordinates of the above Fourth grade Colonels

Colonel of the Western Regions

Colonel of the Western Tribes
Sixth grade, no fixed number of posts

諸無名號者皆此，傳但稱校尉
All colonels without a specific additional title belong to this category; their biographies simply refer to them only as Colonels
鹽府校尉 / 司鹽校尉
Colonel of the Salt Bureau / Colonel for Salt Affairs
(Shu) Account for revenus from salt and metals (Wu) In charge of sea salt affairs

蜀兩稱并用
In Shu this position is known by both names

屬鹽府
Subordinate to the Salt Bureau

Colonel of the Scholar Forest

Colonel of Learning

Colonel Who Illuminates Trust

Colonel Who Proclaims Trust

折鋒見南京薛秋墓
The Colonel Who Breaks the Spear is known from Nanjing's Tomb of Xue Qiu

校事/典校/典校郎/典校事

(Wei) In charge of investigating and impeaching officials
(Wu) In charge of inspecting official documents for misconduct
Fourth grade, Equivalent to 2000 dan, 1 person

魏先置撫軍，后改校事
Wei first established the Commandant Who Conciliates the Army, later changed to Investigator

吳制，校事多別名，屬中書，見長沙竹馬樓竹簡
In Wu, the Investigator often had multiple alternative similar names, and was under the Palace Secretariat, as seen in the Changsha Zumalou documents

天子近臣，奉使出行
Close aides of the emperor, often sent on missions
Fourth grade, Equivalent to 2000 dan, 1 person

積弩都尉/典弩都尉

典鎧都尉

Commandant Who Directs Crossbows

Commandant Who Directs Armor

典弩典鎧同屬積弩將軍
Both commandants were under the Generals of the Crossbows
Fifth grade, no fixed number of posts

諸無名號者皆此，傳但稱都尉
All commandants without a specific additional title belong to this category; their biographies simply refer to them only as Commandants

郡國出鹽者置
Established in commanderies and states with salt resources

郡國有材木者置
Established in commanderies and states with wood resources

每司鹽司竹一人
Each Commandant for Salt Affairs and Commandant for Timber Affairs had one such assistant
